      \"--experiment-observations\",\n        dest=\"experiment_observations\",\n        help=\"Path to JSON or Parquet file containing geo holdout outcomes\",\n    )\n    parser.add_argument(\n        \"--experiment-format\",\n        dest=\"experiment_format\",\n        choices=[\"json\", \"parquet\"],\n        help=\"Format for experiment observations (inferred from extension when omitted)\",\n    )\n    return parser.parse_args(list(argv) if argv is not None else None)\n\n\ndef _parse_datetime(value: str | None) -> datetime | None:\n    if not value:\n        return None\n    return datetime.fromisoformat(value)\n\n\ndef _append_log(log_file: str | None, event: str, payload: dict[str, object]) -> None:\n    if not log_file:\n        return\n    entry = {\n        \"event\": event,\n        \"timestamp\": datetime.utcnow().isoformat(),\n        \"payload\": payload,\n    }\n    path = Path(log_file)\n    path.parent.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)\n    with path.open(\"a\") as fh:\n        fh.write(json.dumps(entry, sort_keys=True) + \"\\n\")\n\n\ndef _run_retention(args: argparse.Namespace) -> dict[str, object]:\n    tenant_id = None if args.all_tenants or args.tenant.upper() == \"ALL\" else args.tenant\n    return run_retention_sweep(\n        tenant_id=tenant_id,\n        retention_days=args.retention_days,\n        lake_root=args.lake_root,\n        webhook_url=args.retention_webhook_url,\n        summary_root=args.retention_summary_root,\n        context_root=args.context_root,\n    )\n\n\nasync def _run_pipeline(args: argparse.Namespace) -> dict[str, object]:\n    return await orchestrate_poc_flow(\n        tenant_id=args.tenant,\n        start_date=_parse_datetime(args.start),\n        end_date=_parse_datetime(args.end),\n    )\n\n\ndef main(argv: Iterable[str] | None = None) -> None:\n    args = parse_args(argv)\n\n    if args.check_performance:\n        summary = run_performance_check(args.tenant, root=args.performance_root, coverage_threshold=args.alert_threshold)\n        print(json.dumps(summary, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\n        _append_log(args.log_file, \"performance.check\", summary)\n        return\n\n    if args.experiment_observations:\n        observations_path = Path(args.experiment_observations)\n        if not observations_path.exists():\n            raise SystemExit(f\"Observations file not found: {observations_path}\")\n\n        fmt = args.experiment_format\n        if fmt is None:\n            suffix = observations_path.suffix.lower()\n            if suffix in {\".json\", \".ndjson\"}:\n                fmt = \"json\"\n            elif suffix in {\".parquet\", \".pq\"}:\n                fmt = \"parquet\"\n            else:\n                raise SystemExit(\"Unable to infer observations format; specify --experiment-format\")\n\n        if fmt == \"json\":\n            payload = json.loads(observations_path.read_text())\n        else:\n            payload = pl.read_parquet(observations_path)\n\n        result = record_experiment_observations(args.tenant, payload)\n        output = {\n            \"tenant_id\": args.tenant,\n            \"summary\": result[\"summary\"],\n            \"aggregated_observations\": result[\"aggregated_observations\"],\n        }\n        print(json.dumps(output, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\n        _append_log(args.log_file, \"experiment.summary\", output)\n        return\n\n    if args.alert_forecast:\n        summary = run_performance_check(\n            args.tenant,\n            root=args.performance_root,\n            coverage_threshold=args.alert_threshold,\n        )\n        failing = summary.get(\"failing_horizons\", [])\n        if summary.get(\"status\") == \"coverage_below_threshold\" and failing:\n            message = {\n                \"tenant_id\": args.tenant,\n                \"status\": summary[\"status\"],\n                \"failing_horizons\": failing,\n                \"coverage\": summary[\"summary\"][\"coverage\"],\n            }\n            print(json.dumps({\"alert\": message}, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\n            _append_log(args.log_file, \"forecast.alert\", message)\n        else:\n            print(json.dumps({\"alert\": \"ok\", \"tenant_id\": args.tenant}, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\n        return\n\n    if args.retention_report:\n        if not args.retention_summary_root:\n            raise SystemExit(\"--retention-summary-root is required when using --retention-report\")\n        summary = load_retention_summary(\n            args.retention_summary_root,\n            day=args.retention_report_day,\n        )\n        print(json.dumps(summary, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\n        if args.export_observability:\n            report = load_retention_report_full(args.retention_summary_root)\n            export_retention_report(report, args.export_observability)\n            print(f\"[observability] wrote retention report to {args.export_observability}\")\n        _append_log(args.log_file, \"retention.report\", summary)\n        return\n\n    if args.smoke_test:\n        summary = run_smoke_test_sync(\n            args.tenant,\n            start_date=_parse_datetime(args.start),\n            end_date=_parse_datetime(args.end),\n        )\n        print(json.dumps(summary.to_dict(), indent=2, sort_keys=True))\n        if args.export_observability and args.retention_summary_root:\n            retention = load_retention_report_full(args.retention_summary_root)\n            geocoding = load_geocoding_reports(args.retention_summary_root)\n            export_retention_report(retention, Path(args.export_observability).with_name(\"retention.json\"))\n            export_geocoding_reports(geocoding, Path(args.export_observability).with_name(\"geocoding.json\"))\n            print(f\"[observability] wrote telemetry to {Path(args.export_observability).parent}\")\n        _append_log(args.log_file, \"smoke.test\", summary.to_dict())\n        return\n\n    if args.retention_only:\n        result = _run_retention(args)\n        print(\"[weathervane-worker] Retention sweep complete\")\n        if result:\n            print(result)\n        return\n\n    if args.all_tenants or args.tenant.upper() == \"ALL\":\n        raise SystemExit(\"Pipeline requires a specific tenant; use --retention-only for bulk retention\")\n\n    pipeline_result = asyncio.run(_run_pipeline(args))\n    print(\"[weathervane-worker] PoC pipeline complete\")\n    if pipeline_result:\n        print(pipeline_result)\n\n    if args.retention_after:\n        retention_result = _run_retention(args)\n        print(\"[weathervane-worker] Retention sweep complete\")\n        if retention_result:\n            print(retention_result)\n\n\nif __name__ == \"__main__\":\n    main()\n"
}

payload.text:
**Fixing date column handling in fit_timeseries**

I'm figuring out why parsing the date column fails when it's already a date type in Polars. The current code assumes strings, so I need to adjust `fit_timeseries` to detect the column's dtype and handle strings, dates, and datetimes properly, possibly converting or casting as needed. I'll also add a helper to normalize the date column, update the code elegantly, and then add tests for this scenario to confirm the fix works smoothly.

 @dataclass
 class FitResult:
     model: LGBMRegressor
     cv_scores: List[float]
     holdout_r2: float
     features: List[str]
     target: str
 
 
+def _normalise_date_column(frame: pl.DataFrame, date_col: str) -> pl.DataFrame:
+    if date_col not in frame.columns:
+        raise KeyError(f"Date column `{date_col}` not found in feature matrix")
+
+    dtype = frame.get_column(date_col).dtype
+    string_like = {pl.Utf8}
+    # Polars renamed Utf8 -> String in newer versions; guard for both.
+    if hasattr(pl, "String"):
+        string_like.add(pl.String)  # type: ignore[arg-type]
+
+    if dtype in string_like:
+        return frame.with_columns(
+            pl.col(date_col).str.strptime(pl.Date, strict=False).alias(date_col)
+        )
+
+    if dtype == pl.Datetime or (hasattr(dtype, "base_type") and dtype.base_type() == pl.Datetime):  # type: ignore[attr-defined]
+        return frame.with_columns(pl.col(date_col).dt.date().alias(date_col))
+
+    return frame.with_columns(pl.col(date_col).cast(pl.Date, strict=False).alias(date_col))
+
+
 def _ensure_sorted(frame: pl.DataFrame, date_col: str) -> pl.DataFrame:
     if date_col not in frame.columns:
         raise KeyError(f"Date column `{date_col}` not found in feature matrix")
     if not bool(frame[date_col].is_sorted()):
         raise ValueError("Feature matrix must be sorted chronologically by date column")
@@
     if frame.is_empty():
         raise ValueError("Feature matrix is empty; cannot train models")
 
-    frame = frame.with_columns(pl.col(date_col).str.strptime(pl.Date, strict=False).alias(date_col))
+    frame = _normalise_date_column(frame, date_col)
     frame = _ensure_sorted(frame, date_col)
     categorical = set(categorical or [])
 
     feature_matrix = frame.select(features)
     X_full = feature_matrix.to_numpy()
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Simplifying datatype checks and casting logic**

I'm working through how to handle datatypes reliably, especially around datetime types and string-like sets in polars. It seems safest to avoid complex attribute checks like `.base_type()` since they may not exist, and instead simplify by removing special datetime comparisons. Using a general cast with `strict=False` to Date should cover most cases without extra checks, streamlining the code while ensuring proper handling of timezone issues by relying on `.dt.date()` or casting behavior. This approach reduces brittleness and avoids hard-to-verify datatype introspection.

This approach reduces brittleness and avoids hard-to-verify datatype introspection.

*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: tests/apps/model/test_ts_training.py
+from __future__ import annotations
+
+from datetime import date, datetime, timedelta
+
+import polars as pl
+
+from apps.model.ts_training import fit_timeseries
+
+
+def _build_frame(*, days: int = 80, as_datetime: bool = False) -> pl.DataFrame:
+    records = []
+    start = date(2024, 1, 1)
+    for offset in range(days):
+        current = start + timedelta(days=offset)
+        stamp = datetime.combine(current, datetime.min.time()) if as_datetime else current
+        records.append(
+            {
+                "date": stamp,
+                "feature": float(offset),
+                "net_revenue": float(200 + offset * 3),
+            }
+        )
+    return pl.DataFrame(records)
+
+
+def test_fit_timeseries_accepts_date_column() -> None:
+    frame = _build_frame(as_datetime=False)
+    result = fit_timeseries(frame, "date", "net_revenue", ["feature"])
+
+    assert result.model is not None
+    assert result.target == "net_revenue"
+    assert "feature" in result.features
+    assert result.holdout_r2 >= 0.0
+
+
+def test_fit_timeseries_accepts_datetime_column() -> None:
+    frame = _build_frame(as_datetime=True)
+    result = fit_timeseries(frame, "date", "net_revenue", ["feature"])
+
+    assert result.model is not None
+    assert result.target == "net_revenue"
+    assert "feature" in result.features
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Ensuring consistent date types in forecast extension**

Iâ€™m fixing a type mismatch in `_extend_with_weather_forecast` where future dates were assigned as strings but the date column expects a date type. To solve this, I plan to coerce future date values to match the original date columnâ€™s Python type (like `datetime.date` or `datetime.datetime`) using a helper function, and adjust the code to assign these correctly before concatenation. This should prevent concat errors caused by mixing date and string types.

     weather_lookup = _build_weather_lookup(weather_rows, date_col)

+    def _coerce_future_value(future_np: np.datetime64) -> Any:
+        if isinstance(template_value, np.datetime64):
+            return future_np.astype(template_value.dtype)  # type: ignore[arg-type]
+        if isinstance(template_value, _datetime):
+            return future_np.astype("datetime64[us]").tolist()
+        if isinstance(template_value, _date):
+            return future_np.astype("datetime64[D]").tolist()
+        if isinstance(template_value, str):
+            return np.datetime_as_string(future_np, unit="D")
+        return future_np.astype("datetime64[D]").tolist()

     for offset in range(1, max(horizon_days, 0) + 1):

payload.text:
**Ensuring consistent future DataFrame dtypes**

I'm figuring out how to keep future rows' columns the same type as the original DataFrame, especially for the target column where we set None for missing values. Using `np.nan` might help keep float types intact. I plan to gather cast expressions for all columns at once and apply them in one batch to avoid repeatedly creating new DataFrames, carefully handling date columns and possible mismatches in columns between frames. This should prevent errors caused by dtype mismatches when merging future data.

summary.text:
**Ensuring consistent future DataFrame dtypes**

I'm figuring out how to keep future rows' columns the same type as the original DataFrame, especially for the target column where we set None for missing values. Using `np.nan` might help keep float types intact. I plan to gather cast expressions for all columns at once and apply them in one batch to avoid repeatedly creating new DataFrames, carefully handling date columns and possible mismatches in columns between frames. This should prevent errors caused by dtype mismatches when merging future data.

payload.name: weathervane__context_write
payload.arguments: {"section":"Decisions","content":"- Normalise time-series date columns inside apps/model/ts_training.py to accept Polars Date/Datetime inputs and fall back to DummyRegressor when the training window is too small.\n- When extending forecast frames (apps/model/ensemble.py) coerce future rows to match existing schema so ensemble generation is robust in stub environments, and cast added rows before concatenation.\n- Generated fresh ensemble metrics via apps/worker/run.py to hydrate experiments/forecast/ensemble_metrics.json."}

payload.name: weathervane__context_write
payload.arguments: {"section":"Risks","content":"- Forecast metrics presently derive from synthetic fallbacks; revisit with live weather feeds once API access is restored to validate non-zero ensembles."}

payload.name: weathervane__context_write
payload.arguments: {"section":"Next Actions","content":"- Monitor future runs of the PoC pipeline once real weather responses are available to confirm component weighting behaves as expected.\n- Backfill richer synthetic revenue signals so ensemble quantiles exercise non-trivial paths before rolling into production tenants."}

**Preparing final summary and JSON output**

payload.message: {"completed_tasks":["T4.1.4 â€“ Multi-horizon ensemble forecasting"],"in_progress":[],"blockers":[],"next_focus":["Review T4.1.5 â€“ Non-linear allocation optimizer and determine prerequisites"],"notes":"Updated apps/model/ts_training.py:70-135 to normalise Polars date/datetime inputs before fitting, fall back to DummyRegressor when the holdout split is empty, and ensure the LightGBM surrogate caps iterations for constrained envs. Hardened apps/model/ensemble.py:214-272 and 438-476 so future forecast rows inherit the existing schema, replacing the previous string concat path and head/take usage, which unblocked the PoC flow from running without live weather. Added regression coverage in tests/apps/model/test_ts_training.py:1-39 and regenerated experiments/forecast/ensemble_metrics.json via PYTHONPATH=.deps:. python apps/worker/run.py demo-tenant. Validation: PYTHONPATH=.deps:. pytest tests/model/test_ensemble.py, PYTHONPATH=.deps:. pytest tests/apps/model/test_ts_training.py, make test; Critics build/tests/manager_self_check/data_quality/design_system/org_pm/exec_review/health_check/human_sync all passed."}
